thread.title: Northern lights photos of Aurora Borealis from October 2024
thread.title_full: Northern lights photos of Aurora Borealis from October 2024

author: Charles Curtis
title: Northern lights photos of Aurora Borealis from October 2024
text:
We’ve seen some absolutely stunning photos in 2024 of the northern lights — AKA Aurora Borealis — but that was back in May.
So why did we see them again in some places you wouldn’t expect in October that produced more amazing photographs in the United States and England? Good question!
Per USA TODAY : It’s “thanks to the “severe” geomagnetic storm forecasted by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. A coronal mass ejection of plasma clouds and charged particles driving the storm prompted NOAA’s Space Prediction Center to issue a rare G4 geomagnetic storm watch for the second time this year .”
Here’s a look at those amazing photos:
1
Aurora borealis, or northern lights, produced by a solar geomagnetic storm are seen over Washington, DC on October 10, 2024. Severe geomagnetic storm conditions could hamper ongoing recovery efforts for Hurricanes Helene and Milton by disrupting satellite communications, power grids and GPS services, the US Space Weather Prediction Center warned October 10, 2024. A coronal mass ejection (CME) struck Earth this morning at 11:17 am (1517 GMT), disrupting the Earth’s magnetic field and quickly achieving G4 (severe) geomagnetic storm conditions at 12:57 pm, the agency said. (Photo by Lucie AUBOURG / AFP) (Photo by LUCIE AUBOURG/AFP via Getty Images)
2
Aurora borealis, or northern lights, produced by a solar geomagnetic storm are seen over Washington, DC on October 10, 2024. Severe geomagnetic storm conditions could hamper ongoing recovery efforts for Hurricanes Helene and Milton by disrupting satellite communications, power grids and GPS services, the US Space Weather Prediction Center warned October 10, 2024. A coronal mass ejection (CME) struck Earth this morning at 11:17 am (1517 GMT), disrupting the Earth’s magnetic field and quickly achieving G4 (severe) geomagnetic storm conditions at 12:57 pm, the agency said. (Photo by Issam AHMED / AFP) (Photo by ISSAM AHMED/AFP via Getty Images)
3
Aurora borealis, or northern lights, produced by a solar geomagnetic storm are seen from Shenandoah National Park in Rileyville, Virginia, on October 10, 2024. A coronal mass ejection from the Sun struck Earth this morning at 11:17 am (1517 GMT), disrupting the Earth’s magnetic field and quickly achieving G4 (severe) geomagnetic storm conditions at 12:57 pm, the US Space Weather Prediction Center said. The event is expected to produce auroras potentially as far south as northern California or Alabama. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP) (Photo by SAUL LOEB/AFP via Getty Images)
4
TOPSHOT – Aurora borealis, or northern lights, produced by a solar geomagnetic storm are seen from Shenandoah National Park in Rileyville, Virginia, on October 10, 2024. A coronal mass ejection from the Sun struck Earth this morning at 11:17 am (1517 GMT), disrupting the Earth’s magnetic field and quickly achieving G4 (severe) geomagnetic storm conditions at 12:57 pm, the US Space Weather Prediction Center said. The event is expected to produce auroras potentially as far south as northern California or Alabama. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP) (Photo by SAUL LOEB/AFP via Getty Images)
5
Photographers take pictures of aurora borealis, or northern lights, produced by a solar geomagnetic storm, seen from Shenandoah National Park in Rileyville, Virginia, on October 10, 2024. A coronal mass ejection from the Sun struck Earth this morning at 11:17 am (1517 GMT), disrupting the Earth’s magnetic field and quickly achieving G4 (severe) geomagnetic storm conditions at 12:57 pm, the US Space Weather Prediction Center said. The event is expected to produce auroras potentially as far south as northern California or Alabama. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP) (Photo by SAUL LOEB/AFP via Getty Images)
6
Aurora borealis, or northern lights, produced by a solar geomagnetic storm are seen from Shenandoah National Park in Rileyville, Virginia, on October 10, 2024. A coronal mass ejection from the Sun struck Earth this morning at 11:17 am (1517 GMT), disrupting the Earth’s magnetic field and quickly achieving G4 (severe) geomagnetic storm conditions at 12:57 pm, the US Space Weather Prediction Center said. The event is expected to produce auroras potentially as far south as northern California or Alabama. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP) (Photo by SAUL LOEB/AFP via Getty Images)
7
Trees around Nyack Middle School are seen as aurora borealis, or northern lights, produced by a solar geomagnetic storm lights the sky in Nyack, New York, on October 11, 2024. A coronal mass ejection from the Sun struck Earth this morning at 11:17 am (1517 GMT), disrupting the Earth’s magnetic field and quickly achieving G4 (severe) geomagnetic storm conditions at 12:57 pm, the US Space Weather Prediction Center said. The event is expected to produce auroras potentially as far south as northern California or Alabama. (Photo by Kena Betancur / AFP) (Photo by KENA BETANCUR/AFP via Getty Images)
8
HERNE BAY, UNITED KINGDOM – OCTOBER 11: The aurora borealis light up the night sky behind the Reculver Towers and Roman Fort on October 11, 2024 in Herne Bay, United Kingdom. The Aurora Borealis or Northern Lights result from geomagnetic storms and were seen as far southern england overnight on the 10th October. (Photo by Dan Kitwood/Getty Images)
9
HERNE BAY, UNITED KINGDOM – OCTOBER 11: The aurora borealis light up the night sky behind the Reculver Towers and Roman Fort on October 11, 2024 in Herne Bay, United Kingdom. The Aurora Borealis or Northern Lights result from geomagnetic storms and were seen as far southern england overnight on the 10th October. (Photo by Dan Kitwood/Getty Images)
